title: How to Repair Wicker Furniture

steps.headline: Scan the furniture for loose ends.
steps.description: Examine your wicker furniture to spot any pieces poking out. Do this in a well-lit area, or use a map lamp or flashlight to see things clearly. Use your hands to feel for loose ends in place that you may not be able to examine easily close up.

steps.headline: Use wood glue to fix them.
steps.description: Apply a drop or 2 of wood glue to the bottom of any loose ends that are sticking out. Carefully tuck them back into the wicker pattern by pulling the strands together. Hold down the glued pieces for several seconds to allow them to bond to the chair. Do this for each loose strand you find.

steps.headline: Let the glue dry for 30 minutes.
steps.description: Once you have tucked in and glued all the loose ends, allow the glue to dry. Avoid touching the furniture for a full 30 minutes so the adhesive can take hold. For the best results, leave the item of furniture in a cool, dry room during this time.

steps.headline: Remove broken strands of wicker.
steps.description: Use heavy-duty scissors or an exacto knife to cut loose strands out of your wicker furniture. Carefully snip through damaged strands near the underside of arms, legs, or other parts of the piece. gently pull out the damaged strands to avoid damaging other parts of the wicker.

steps.headline: Soak replacement reeds in warm water for 30 minutes to make them flexible.
steps.description: Select the replacement reeds you need to fix your damaged wicker furniture. Place them in a large container full of warm water. Let them sit in the water for 30 minutes.

steps.headline: Remove excess water from the reeds.
steps.description: Remove the reeds from the water and place them on a pile of clean paper towels. Gently press on the reeds with another paper towel to drain out excess water. Continue pressing on them with fresh paper towels until no more water comes out.

steps.headline: Weave the replacement reeds into the wicker furniture.
steps.description: Thread a replacement reed into the furniture, starting from a point near the back that is less visible. Using pliers or your fingers, gently weave the reed in an out of the wicker. Follow the pattern of the wicker for the best results.

steps.headline: Glue the strands in place.
steps.description: Once the reed is all the way through, add a drop of wood glue to the ends. Tuck them in to keep them from sticking out. Gently hold the stands in place for several seconds to allow the glue to set.

steps.headline: Secure the ends with carpet tacks after 30 minutes.
steps.description: Insert carpet tacks right on the ends of the replacement reeds once the wood glue is dry. Gently push the tacks in to avoid splitting the reed fibers. Use your finger or a small hammer to make sure the tack are securely firmly.

steps.headline: Clean the cushions.
steps.description: Wicker furniture that has cushions may be more prone to attracting odors, dust, and dirt. If possible, remove the cushioned parts of your furniture for cleaning. If they have removable covers, clean them in the washing machine and allow them to air dry. If they do not have removable covers, bring them to be professionally cleaned or use a wet vacuum to remove stains and odors.

steps.headline: Apply a cleaning solution of bleach and water to the surface of your wicker furniture.
steps.description: In a large bucket, mix 1 litre (4.2  c) of water and 250 millilitres (1.1  c) of household bleach. Use a clean cloth soaked in this solution to wipe down your wicker furniture. Allow it to air dry for 2-3 hours. This solution will deodorize wicker and remove stains. Use gloves when applying this solution.

steps.headline: Refinish the wicker by applying a primer for a clean finish.
steps.description: Place the wicker furniture outdoors or in a well-ventilated area. Spray a thin layer of resin-based primer over the entire surface of your wicker furniture. Let it dry for 2-3 hours. Hold the can 2–3 inches (5.1–7.6 cm) away from the furniture when spraying it. Wear a mask to avoid inhaling fumes.

text: Repairing Loose Ends Scan the furniture for loose ends. Examine your wicker furniture to spot any pieces poking out. Do this in a well-lit area, or use a map lamp or flashlight to see things clearly. Use your hands to feel for loose ends in place that you may not be able to examine easily close up. Use wood glue to fix them. Apply a drop or 2 of wood glue to the bottom of any loose ends that are sticking out. Carefully tuck them back into the wicker pattern by pulling the strands together. Hold down the glued pieces for several seconds to allow them to bond to the chair. Do this for each loose strand you find. Let the glue dry for 30 minutes. Once you have tucked in and glued all the loose ends, allow the glue to dry. Avoid touching the furniture for a full 30 minutes so the adhesive can take hold. For the best results, leave the item of furniture in a cool, dry room during this time. Replacing Broken Reeds Remove broken strands of wicker. Use heavy-duty scissors or an exacto knife to cut loose strands out of your wicker furniture. Carefully snip through damaged strands near the underside of arms, legs, or other parts of the piece. gently pull out the damaged strands to avoid damaging other parts of the wicker. Soak replacement reeds in warm water for 30 minutes to make them flexible. Select the replacement reeds you need to fix your damaged wicker furniture. Place them in a large container full of warm water. Let them sit in the water for 30 minutes. Remove excess water from the reeds. Remove the reeds from the water and place them on a pile of clean paper towels. Gently press on the reeds with another paper towel to drain out excess water. Continue pressing on them with fresh paper towels until no more water comes out. Weave the replacement reeds into the wicker furniture. Thread a replacement reed into the furniture, starting from a point near the back that is less visible. Using pliers or your fingers, gently weave the reed in an out of the wicker. Follow the pattern of the wicker for the best results. Glue the strands in place. Once the reed is all the way through, add a drop of wood glue to the ends. Tuck them in to keep them from sticking out. Gently hold the stands in place for several seconds to allow the glue to set. Secure the ends with carpet tacks after 30 minutes. Insert carpet tacks right on the ends of the replacement reeds once the wood glue is dry. Gently push the tacks in to avoid splitting the reed fibers. Use your finger or a small hammer to make sure the tack are securely firmly. Cleaning Wicker Furniture Clean the cushions. Wicker furniture that has cushions may be more prone to attracting odors, dust, and dirt. If possible, remove the cushioned parts of your furniture for cleaning. If they have removable covers, clean them in the washing machine and allow them to air dry. If they do not have removable covers, bring them to be professionally cleaned or use a wet vacuum to remove stains and odors. Apply a cleaning solution of bleach and water to the surface of your wicker furniture. In a large bucket, mix 1 litre (4.2  c) of water and 250 millilitres (1.1  c) of household bleach. Use a clean cloth soaked in this solution to wipe down your wicker furniture. Allow it to air dry for 2-3 hours. This solution will deodorize wicker and remove stains. Use gloves when applying this solution. Refinish the wicker by applying a primer for a clean finish. Place the wicker furniture outdoors or in a well-ventilated area. Spray a thin layer of resin-based primer over the entire surface of your wicker furniture. Let it dry for 2-3 hours. Hold the can 2–3 inches (5.1–7.6 cm) away from the furniture when spraying it. Wear a mask to avoid inhaling fumes.

Examine your wicker furniture to spot any pieces poking out.
Do this in a well-lit area, or use a map lamp or flashlight to see things clearly.
Use your hands to feel for loose ends in place that you may not be able to examine easily close up.
Use wood glue to fix them.
Apply a drop or 2 of wood glue to the bottom of any loose ends that are sticking out.
Carefully tuck them back into the wicker pattern by pulling the strands together.
Hold down the glued pieces for several seconds to allow them to bond to the chair.
Do this for each loose strand you find.
Let the glue dry for 30 minutes.
Once you have tucked in and glued all the loose ends, allow the glue to dry.
Avoid touching the furniture for a full 30 minutes so the adhesive can take hold.
For the best results, leave the item of furniture in a cool, dry room during this time.
Replacing Broken Reeds Remove broken strands of wicker.
Use heavy-duty scissors or an exacto knife to cut loose strands out of your wicker furniture.
Carefully snip through damaged strands near the underside of arms, legs, or other parts of the piece.
gently pull out the damaged strands to avoid damaging other parts of the wicker.
Soak replacement reeds in warm water for 30 minutes to make them flexible.
Select the replacement reeds you need to fix your damaged wicker furniture.
Place them in a large container full of warm water.
Let them sit in the water for 30 minutes.
Remove excess water from the reeds.
Remove the reeds from the water and place them on a pile of clean paper towels.
Gently press on the reeds with another paper towel to drain out excess water.
Continue pressing on them with fresh paper towels until no more water comes out.
Weave the replacement reeds into the wicker furniture.
Thread a replacement reed into the furniture, starting from a point near the back that is less visible.
Using pliers or your fingers, gently weave the reed in an out of the wicker.
Follow the pattern of the wicker for the best results.
Glue the strands in place.
Once the reed is all the way through, add a drop of wood glue to the ends.
Tuck them in to keep them from sticking out.
Gently hold the stands in place for several seconds to allow the glue to set.
Secure the ends with carpet tacks after 30 minutes.
Insert carpet tacks right on the ends of the replacement reeds once the wood glue is dry.
Gently push the tacks in to avoid splitting the reed fibers.
Use your finger or a small hammer to make sure the tack are securely firmly.
Cleaning Wicker Furniture Clean the cushions.
Wicker furniture that has cushions may be more prone to attracting odors, dust, and dirt.
If possible, remove the cushioned parts of your furniture for cleaning.
If they have removable covers, clean them in the washing machine and allow them to air dry.
If they do not have removable covers, bring them to be professionally cleaned or use a wet vacuum to remove stains and odors.
Apply a cleaning solution of bleach and water to the surface of your wicker furniture.
In a large bucket, mix 1 litre (4.2  c) of water and 250 millilitres (1.1  c) of household bleach.
Use a clean cloth soaked in this solution to wipe down your wicker furniture.
Allow it to air dry for 2-3 hours.
This solution will deodorize wicker and remove stains.
Use gloves when applying this solution.
Refinish the wicker by applying a primer for a clean finish.
Place the wicker furniture outdoors or in a well-ventilated area.
Spray a thin layer of resin-based primer over the entire surface of your wicker furniture.
Let it dry for 2-3 hours.
Hold the can 2–3 inches (5.1–7.6 cm) away from the furniture when spraying it.
Wear a mask to avoid inhaling fumes.
